comments.commentBody: Either works!
Do you use fresh ground peanut butter, or something processed, like Jif?

Unrelated to music Friday. On inequality. Darwin: "If the misery of the poor be caused not by the laws of nature, but by our institutions, great is our sin."

Yes, our institutions. Adam Smith: "The difference of natural talents in different men is, in reality, much less than we are aware of... The difference between the most dissimilar characters, between a philosopher and a common street porter, for example, seems to arise not so much from nature as from habit, custom, and education. When they came into the world, and for the first six or eight years of their existence, they were, perhaps, very much alike, and neither their parents nor playfellows could perceive any remarkable difference. About that age, or soon after, they come to be employed in very different occupations. The difference of talents comes then to be taken notice of, and widens by degrees, till at last the vanity of the philosopher is willing to acknowledge scarce any resemblance."

Human diversity is inevitable. Social inequality, a hierarchical social order is not, and increasingly it is morally intolerable. Just like different skin color cannot justify the enslavement of ones by others or sexual differences cannot justify patriarchy and gender exploitation, differences in physical propensities or modes of learning, often reinforced by historical inequities that pass from generation to generation, are unacceptable as alibis for a vertical social order.

Hi Jon P,
Its good to hear from someone else who values meditation.
I googled "meditation and cognitive enhancement" and
a raft of websites showed up, to include scholarly articles, that support my argument.

In my opinion, the effect of regular practice is an overall clarity. In addition to daily meditative practice, I read widely (literary as well as technical and scientific subjects), study chess, do woodworking, exercise, and do lots of other things that require me to think.

In my seventh decade of life, yes, I have of late noticed that sometimes I grope for a word, but I consider meditation to be
a very effective tool in my quest to think as clearly as I ever did throughout my life.

"But where's the proof that it will maintain our cognitive function throughout life? Are there studies that show meditation prevents dementia or even normal memory loss caused by aging of the brain?"

Where is the proof that what Lumosity promises to do for a monthly fee is superior to what meditation promises to do at no charge?

Note that _Lumosity_ is a registered trademark, whereas _meditation_ is just a random word, free for use by anyone and everyone.
Evidence, please. I don’t doubt you “feel” better with your practice, but is the evidence there? I am talking about high-quality trials with published results.

The problem of maintaining cognitive functioning throughout life was solved thousands of years ago, when humans developed meditation techniques that have you focus on your breathing.

The "trick" is in continually noticing when your attention wanders, and then bringing your mind back to following your breath. Not forcing your breathing, just watching it. This form of meditation trains the mind to be grounded in the the present and fosters mental clarity.

My preferred practice is "standing zen" meditation, but there are any number of eastern meditation disciplines that work, too.

And they don't need to cost you anything.

Hi Lisa.  I'm a School Psychologist -  The reason they object is because simply determining what intelligence and cognition are is a task in and of itself.   The issue is not with the games themselves; it is with billing them as a way to affect dementia/forgetfulness or whatever other disorder they claimed it would help.  False, very very false, advertising.    Certainly it's best to use your brain.  The Dana Foundation has published good work on this - you can best hedge against dementia with a couple of activities: If you don't play an instrument, learn how and get proficient (really proficient) in music.  Might get you a postponement of about 6 years.  Or learn a language you don't know.  Neither of these things is typically seen as "entertainment" and that's the key - things that may help will involve real cognitive work - we all know learning a language is not a play project.

"Plenty of folks young and old pay for various electronic forms of entertainment."

But the "science of Lumosity" is not advertised as a mere "game." Rather, Lumosity is a "science." You know, like physics or chemistry or biology.

Learning a new language can be lots of fun particularly if done with other people. As for music, only a music lover would put alll that time and effort to learn to play an instrument and so it too would be enjoyable.

Learning at any age can be fun.

I have to wonder the motive for some psychologists and neuroscientists objecting.  I mean,  either way these games can't hurt.  Plenty of folks young  and old pay for various electronic forms of entertainment.  Maybe their claims stretched a bit,  but better to give your brain any kind of activity than none at all.  Maybe some in the industry feared Lumosity really might  help, and then their crony pharma friends might find less people paying for their drugs???
There are many such auto-billing plans, and not just targeted at the elderly.  NYT online subscription anyone?  ;-)

I question whether the Republicans are really looking for a more centrist alternative, or merely that we NYT readers are. If one looks at the comments posted in the WSJ's election articles, their readers blame President Obama for everything, and seem very content with both Mr. Trump and Mr. Cruz. What gets lost in most commentaries is that this country is split rather close to 50-50 between Republicans and Democrats, and while those of us left of center keep hoping that a more centrist alternative to the extreme Right candidates will arise, the other half of the country is rather happy with their options.

My take on this election cycle;
Fox secretly wants a democrat to win the White House. They have made a fortune beating up and kicking around President Obama for the past eight years. Think of all those conspiracies they'd miss stirring up like they did with Ebola virus, Jade Helm, etc.

If we want better candidates that resemble America, we should change the primary schedule.  We do not need three conservative small states two of which are mainly white to start off the primaries.  Our country has changed and more people live in the cities and suburbs among a diverse population.  We need a big state or one with a big city and diverse population.Then we would have less donalds and more normals.

You nailed it:  after 7 years of racism, hate, homophobia, sexism, insane conspiracies, unprecedented treason, obstruction and absolutely no respect for the country or the office of the President, FrankenTrump = the Republican party.  That's how vile they've gotten.

The Republican party is in the process of splitting into two different parties. This will happen this election or the next. for sure.
This division is not over which is the most "conservative". That is the standard left/right fallacy of politics.

If you want to understand politics, you have to go beyond this one-dimensional left/right categorization, and understand that there is a second political dimension, which does not have a name, but which might be called the Social (authoritarian) /Individualistic dimension

Trump and Cruz are battling on this second dimension. Trump is the authoritarian; Cruz is the individualist. (aka Libertarian).

What is the intent of the Framers with respect to the phrase "natural born citizen?"

I submit that the intent of the Framers is that the qualifications for citizenship for the purposes of being President of the United States was to be held to a higher standard than the qualifications for mere citizenship.

My reading of the correspondence and discussion that went into the phrase lead me to believe that the phrase is grounded in the English Common Law of Colonial and Revolutionary America - born of two citizens subject to the Crown and in a jurisdiction subject to the Crown.

Cruz is prohibited from being President of the United States by Article 2 for two reasons - born of (a) non citizen parent(s) in a foreign jurisdiction.

My question is purely hypothetical and was posted to try to understand the law. Mt daughter has no interest in politics. Having said that, I am very proud for having served and your comment is unnecessarily personal.

I watch these debates like people watch horrible car accidents, unable to turn away. Let's face it, this is a horror show. The only thing worse than these two candidates are the crowds who cheer, hoot, whistle and shout for them.

What will happen to our country after President Trump or President Cruz is elected?

1. The defunded and denigrated school systems created two universes by producing a "less informed" electorate that fails recognize demagogary.
2. The tax and deregulatory policies under Republican control created two universes.
3. The acquiesence to importation of jobs by U.S. corporations have produced two universes.

While these guys compete to be the bigger bully, trading insults, real things are going on every day that they don't say a word about. Jakarta, Burkino Faso to name a couple. They have nothing to say about the reality of being the Commander in Chief, only things like, "I'm great! That guy's a loser!" or "His birth certificate would disqualify him!"

Candidates should speak in specific terms with clear examples of what they would do about things that are happening every day from now until the election.

I believe Sanders also has dual citizenship (Israel) and he should also be disqualified. The loyalty of the highest office holder should not be questionable, which dual citizenship implies for most voters.

Why does the headline read, in part, "G.O.P. Looks for an Alternate"?  You mean the GOP establishment, which isn't the party.  I'm no fan of the GOP clowns, but your characterization removes the "democracy" part of the democratic process.  They'll nominate a candidate that fits the mood of their membership, not one chosen in a smoke-filled room.
Of *course* he's un-American: with a Cuban father and a mother who, by voting in Canadian elections, effectively renounced her US citizenship.
"all the terrifying problems that Obama has caused": Please give at least one example.

I don't see why anyone would watch a political debate.  I can get more than enough information from the media reports on what happened at the debate.  Actually watching it?  I'd rather get waterboarded at Abu Ghraib

Oh, yes! Marco, the reasoned voice of the moderate republican conservatives. As my friend best said, here is the Marco agenda......
- get rid of Obamacare
- spend billions more on the already bloated military
- cut taxes (of course)
Let's see, let our people die and let's go to war!
What could be more moderate?
The signal to noise ratio of the republican debates and candidates is threatening to drop below zero.
Trump has too much money and Cruz cannot remember he has borrowed money. They make a good pair, don't they?
It's hard to believe that Lincoln was a Republican given the party now. He must be rolling in his grave.
I don't know how these alternate universes were created but they scare the hell out of me.  These Republican debates are a snippet of a nursery school argument.

Perhaps but he's still an ethically loose, lying, bigoted, misogynistic, narcissism, bombastic buffoon.....and all of the above were truly the kindest things I could come up with.

I would not:
- work with him
- work for him
- break bread with him
- let him enter my house
- speak to my children
- borrow a stick of gum from him

He might have all the money in the world, and yes he's running for president, but I have more respect for the slugs in the yard than I do for that moron.

He could be from green Mars, and it would not mitigate that his candidacy is an embarrassment but his presidency would be colossal disaster.
